Furthermore‚ Aristotle in his Problems determines the question, why the ancients proposed prizes to the stronger in gym- nastic and corporeal contests, but never awarded any prize for wisdom. This question he solves as follows: In gymnastic exercises the prize is better and more desirable than that for which it is be· stowed3 but it is certain that nothing is better than wisdom: wherefore no prize could be as· signed for wisdom. And therefore neither riches nor delights are more excellent than wisdom. 32 Again‚ only the fool 'will deny that friendship is to be preferred to riches, since the wisest of men testifies this3 but the chief of philosophers honours truth before friendship, and the truthful Zorobabel prefers it to all things. Riches then are less than truth. Now truth is chiefly maintained and con· tained in holy books—hay they are written truth itself, since by books we do not now mean the materials of which they are made.
